May 15 1857
Friend Andy
I enclose to you the
late news from Lower California
It is fearfull -- particularly so when you
come to know that Crabb, McCoun
Wood and Dr Oxley were acquaintances
of mine -- haveing known them along
time in this country
Henry A. Crabb served the county
to which I belonged for a long time in this
country, as Senator, served his term
of two years with credit to himself and
the State of California.  Col. W. H.
McCoun, did the same thing, for
the same district with same results
Col. Wood represented San Francisco
in the Assembly Dr. Oxley
represented Tuolumene County in
the Assembly two terms received
a respectful vote for Speaker of
the house.  Henry A. Crabb came
near being the United States Senator
from this State under the Know Nothing

administration.
All the names I have mentioned
were prominent "Know Nothing"
politicians.
Though I did not agree with 
them in politics, I grieve at
the loss of such friends and
acquaintances
Col Wood was on the "Fillmore
Electoral ticket" for this State
Crabb, previous to his turn
over to Know Nothingism, was
considered the leader of the old
Whig party on this Coast
Crabb and Wood leave Families
to mourn their loss.
The deaths of such men as
composed a part of this party, will
create a profound sensation throughout
this state.  I do not
sanction the movement of this
party; there is but one mitigation
for the offense committed upon Mexico
by these men.  I will give it
for all it is worth, It is the
only thing I know of to put in

to put in the scale in their fame?
Being well acquainted with the
leaders of this part, latly massacred
in cold blood.  I was let into
some of the secrets of the movement.
Crabb, I was told had
been invited to Sonora by some
of the leading citizens of that
state to bring enough men with
him to make a show -- take 
charge of the government, and
protect the ? Borders from the
Indians -- and make Sonora
free and Independent of
Mexico -- that the larger portions
of the inhabitants would join his
standard?, and the thing could be
easily done.  In fact was put
down as a "Bloodless victory" --
fatal mistake!
Now this looks reasonable when
you come to know that Crabb
had just returned from Sonora
-- that his wife was a Spanish
woman -- and belonged to an aristocratic
family -- he had three
Brother-in-laws in this country two

were Brothers of his wife -- one
married a sister of his wife.  
(Rasey? Bisen? (one of his bro in laws name) an American, was at
one time Editor, and proprietor of a
a paper called the "Evening Post"
published in Stockton, was also one
of the Clerks of the Senate of this
state, one session.)  All these facts
gives this "Filibustering Expedition"
a little different coloring
from what is has in the different
papers of the day
I also enclose to you some Editoral
on the subject to show how
the Massacre is looked upon by
the press of this city
My regards to all.  Continue
to send my papers to Stockton
though I am now located in
San Francisco.  I will get them
more promptly from that office than
I would from this -- because I
am constantly traveling through
the State, and it makes but

very little difference where my
letters and papers are sent.
the Clerk in my different offices
always looks out for them
Your ? ?
J. M. Vansyckle
